publisher: Intergovernmental Authority on Development Climate and Applications Centre
blurb: The Intergovernmental Authority on Development Climate and Applications Centre developed the Agriculture Monitoring for Eastern Africa, which observes croplands to build resilience in areas affected by climate change. Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Sudan and Uganda formed IGADD in 1986 to reduce the impacts of natural disasters such as droughts.

Berkley Earth is a US-based non-profit supplying open-source temperature change and air pollution data which started in 2010 to address global warming sceptics. It gathers data from weather stations. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the Washington Post, New York Times, National Geographic and Scientific American have all used its data.

report: BP Statistical Review of World Energy
blurb: BP supplied access to statistics on world energy use for 70 years. It covered oil production, renewable energy and energy consumption. In 2023, it handed its custodianship of the project to the Energy Institute. The report aims to supply timely and objective global energy production, consumption and emission data.
tags: oil, gas, coal, nuclear, renewables, hydroelectricity, mining

report: Centre for Environmental Data Analysis – satellite observations
blurb: UK-based Centre for Environmental Data Analysis aims to work with the science environmental community by archiving big data and using new technologies to enhance satellite-captured information. It works with National Centre for Atmospheric Science and the National Centre for Earth Observation. CEDA started from the merger of two data centres.

Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS) is an almost global rain dataset focussing on Africa and Asia. It began collecting data in 1981 and uses satellite footage from NOAA and NASA. UK-based Water Resource Associates manages the CHIRP data and extracts it for clients for a fee.

publisher: Center for Hydrometeorology and Remote Sensing
blurb: The University of California, Irvine's Center for Hydrometeorology and Remote Sensing (CHRS) data portal uses satellite information to estimate global and regional rainfall. The project aims to 'advance the knowledge of the water and energy cycles'. NASA, NOAA and the NSF fund CHRS. It is an interdisciplinary research project.

publisher: Center for Hydrometeorology and Remote Sensing
blurb: The University of California, Irvine's Center for Hydrometeorology and Remote Sensing (CHRS) data portal uses satellite information to estimate global and regional rainfall over 72 hours. The project aims to track real-time extreme weather events and observe precipitation. Unesco, the US Army's ICIWaRM and NASA have funded the two-decade project

publisher: Center for Hydrometeorology and Remote Sensing
blurb: The University of California, Irvine's Center for Hydrometeorology and Remote Sensing (CHRS) rain sphere uses satellite information to estimate global and regional precipitation and improve people's understanding of climate change. Dr Phu Nguyen runs the project with the assistance of undergraduate students. UNESCO, the US Army, NASA and NOAA fund it.

US-based Non-profit Climate Central works on gathering big data to make climate change personal and help find solutions. It began in 2008 to promote understanding of global warming, with funding from the Flora Family Foundation and the 11th Hour Project. Its data featured at the 2021 UN Climate Conference.

Started in 2016, the Climate Impact Lab is a non-profit founded by the University of Chicago’s Energy Policy Institute, the University of California, Berkeley, Rhodium Group and Rutgers University. It uses historical socioeconomic and climate data to show how climate change has and will impact societies.

The World Bank's Climate Knowledge Portal is an interactive portal with an aggregation of data on national, sub-national, and watershed scales. It supplies information on national hazards and socio-economic conditions. It provides historical and projected climate data and sources it from the University of East Anglia's Climatic Research Unit.

Launched in 2005, the United Nations launched UNdata to provide free access to global statistics in partnership with Statistics Sweden and the Gapminder Foundation. The dataset uses country-produced data, projections and estimates. The UN's Environment Stats database has information from 1990 to 2015 on emissions, water treatment and energy consumption.

The European-based Copernicus Climate Change data uses satellite imagery to measure temperature and precipitation. It began to support the mitigation and adaptation policies of the European Union, which funds it, by providing 'consistent and authoritative information about climate change'. It works with CNN and Euronews.

publisher: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis
blurb: In 2009, the US-based University of New Mexico established Data One to help scientists understand the nature of change on Earth. It is a community-driven data repository focussing on environmental data. By 2019, the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis at UC Santa Barbara managed the programme.

Germany-based Deutscher Wetterdienst supplies climate prediction and monitoring data for Germany, Europe and the globe. It is funded by the German government. Its role is to supply the fields of transport, trade and industry, agriculture and forestry, the building industry, public health, and water management with meteorological and climatological services.

Digital Earth Africa Map is made of data sourced from satellite imagery to visualise climate change, urbanisation and flood risk on the continent. The US-based Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust and the Australian Government funded the project in 2019. By 2022 Geoscience Australia handed the project to a South African company.

publisher: Intergovernmental Authority on Development Climate and Applications Centre
blurb: The Intergovernmental Authority on Development Climate and Applications Centre manages the East Africa Drought Watch, which measures rainfall, groundwater levels and soil moisture. The dashboard is an adaptation of the European Drought Observatory. The European Commission, Sahara and Sahel Observatory, Adaptation Fund and Global Water partnered to make the dashboard possible.

publisher: Intergovernmental Authority on Development Climate and Applications Centre
blurb: East Africa Hazards Watch uses data from CHIRPS and WRF to visualise temperature, rainfall and to track extreme weather events. The African-based Intergovernmental Authority on Development manages the project. It began in 2023 to help protect populations in East Africa and increase their resilience, like tracking areas at risk of crop failures.
tags: temperature, rainfall, cyclones, droughts, flood, food security

blurb: The United Nations Environment Programme, founded in 1972, supplies data on the state of the climate and progress on reducing greenhouse gas emissions to address environmental challenges and improve quality of life without compromising the earth for future generations. It sources data from Net Zero Tracker, Climate Watch and UN DESA.

World Resources Unit manages the Climate Watch project. It came about to allow researchers, policymakers and the media to review the global progress on climate change and the nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement. Google and several government agencies fund the project with data contributions from several universities and institutes.

report: Energy Institute's Statistical Review of World Energy
blurb: The Energy Institute is an independent, professional body for energy. Data is collected by Centre for Energy Economics Research and Policy at Heriot-Watt University. The project is supported by BP and funded by KPMG and Kearney. It aims to supply timely and objective global energy production, consumption and emission data.
tags: oil, gas, coal, nuclear, renewables, hydroelectricity, mining

report: Flood exposure and poverty in 188 countries
blurb: A 2022 Nature Communications report on 'Flood exposure and poverty in 188 countries' details what proportion of a population is at risk of flooding in each country. The researchers came from the World Bank, Payne Institute, University College London, Deltares and Delft University. Flood hazard data was sourced from Fathom Global.

Nasa supplies the surface temperature data from 1961 for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Association statistics. The data covers 245 countries. Its goal is to provide policymakers with the information to 'make sure that people have regular access to enough high-quality food to lead active, healthy lives,

report: Edgar - Emissions Data for Global Atmospheric Research
blurb: The European Commission supplies an Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research focusing on emissions from the energy, building, and transport industries, greenhouse gases and air pollutants. The database compares emission estimates of 220 countries. Researchers and the United Nations use the data which dates back to 1970.

Global Carbon Project maintains the Global Carbon Atlas. The project started in 2001. Future Earth and the World Climate Research Programme established it to provide mutually agreed upon knowledge which would help policymakers 'slow down and ultimately stop the increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere'. The Atlas supplies emissions data.

UK-based donor-funded Our World in Data is an aggregator of datasets from across the globe. Its emissions data is sourced from a Statistical review of world energy, the Global carbon budget and the International Energy Agency. Publishers have used the data extensively from the New York Times to The Guardian.

Global Forest Watch, launched in 2014, monitors forests across the globe, from deforestation to fires. An early version of the project was piloted in 1997, reporting on Cameroon, Canada, Gabon and Indonesia. Many foundations including, the Bezos Earth Fund, UK AID, and Agence Française Développement, have partnered with the project.

Nasa and Japan's Aerospace Exploration established Global Precipitation Measurement in 2014. It is an international network of satellites observing rain and snow. It aims to advance scientists understanding of the planet's water cycles and standardised precipitation measurements. NOAA, European, Indian and French research and meteorological agencies support the project.

The European-based EMEP programme, formed in 1979, measures air pollution (including Nitrogen Oxides, Sulphur Dioxides and particulate matter) and overall emissions from counties. The  Norwegian Meteorological Institute hosts the programme. Scientists use the data for technical reports. The data is focused on European countries, the United States and North Africa.

UK-based commercial Research and Development Organisation Institute for Environmental Analytics supplies weather and climate modelling for businesses and governments. It began in 2015 and focuses on renewable energy and modelling energy production for future renewable construction sites. It has collaborated with South African engineering countries rolling out solar power.

The Global Carbon Project researchers publish data on the Global Carbon Budget annually. The Budget monitors the amount of human-induced carbon emissions into the atmosphere against the storage of carbon in land and ocean reservoirs. The Budget uses data from the Integrated Carbon Observation System. The project began in 2001.

The International Monetary Fund dashboard on climate change, launched in 2021, aims to help understand the links between economic and government policies and climate change, focusses on carbon emissions from different industries. The Food and Agriculture Organization and NASA databases supply the data, which is funded by IMF member states.
tags: emissions, forest cover, disasters, sea level, temperature

report: IPCC WGI Interactive Atlas: Regional information (Advanced)
blurb: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change released an interactive dashboard showcasing the data it used for its Sixth Assessment Report report designed for the media, teachers and decision-makers. The rainfall, snowfall, wind speed, and surface and ocean temperature data reflect observations and climate models. The Spanish government funded the dashboard.

The US-based IRI Data Library is a freely accessible data repository run by Columbia Climate School and established to anticipate and manage the impacts of climate to improve human welfare. The data covers large regions and is not country-specific. However, data for the continent of Africa is available.

Independent European non-profit think tank Ember releases an annual report on the state of energy, focussing on the shift to renewables to cut down carbon emissions. It began in 2008 to reform the EU carbon market and rebranded in 2020. The WWF and the European Climate Foundation are its funders.
tags: emissions, energy, gas, hydroelectricity, nuclear, oil, renewables

blurb: Tunis-based L'Observatoire du Sahara et du Sahel has a dashboard tracking the temperature, land coverage and rainfall for North Africa. The Green Climate Fund and Adaptation Fund financed the project, which began in 1992. The project aims to manage shared water resources sustainably during a time of climate change.

The Monitoring Integrated System for Land Degradation Monitoring, MISLAND, is a collaborative effort with the Global Monitoring for Environment and Security funded by the African Union and European Commission. The project uses earth observation to realise 'land degradation neutrality'. It measures desertification, coastal erosion and forest loss.

NASA's earth science data system is free, open-source data. The United States government funds the programme. NASA collects data from satellite imagery, space missions, observatories and laboratories. Thousands of scientists and coders analyse the climate data, which covers ice cover, ocean and atmospheric change, and carbon emissions to global temperatures.

report: Nasa Goddard Institute for Space Studies – GISS Surface Temperature Analysis
blurb: NASA's earth science data system is free, open-source data. The United States government funds the programme. NASA collects data from satellite imagery, space missions, observatories and laboratories. Thousands of scientists and coders analyse the climate data, which covers ice cover, ocean and atmospheric change, and carbon emissions to global temperatures.

Established in 1970, the US-based scientific and regulatory body National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Agency aims to convert 'scientific insights into dynamic, usable information that informs strategy and decision-making'. Data is collected through satellite imagery to forecast weather and measure atmospheric and ocean conditions. The US government funds the programme.

The International Energy Agency works with governments, agencies and forums to 'ensure secure, affordable and sustainable energy systems'. It forms a part of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which funds it. The IEA has 31 member countries, 13 association countries and four accession countries.

The International Energy Agency works with governments, agencies and forums to 'ensure secure, affordable and sustainable energy systems'. It forms a part of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which funds it. The IEA has 31 member countries, 13 association countries and four accession countries.

US-based NASA's Precipitation Processing System (PPS) processes and archives satellite data from the joint NASA and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency project, the Global Precipitation Measurement. PPS began from the Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission, which stopped collecting satellite data in 2015. PPS supplies algorithms and data for scientists.

Rain Watch is an African-based data collection project which aims to supply real-time rainfall monitoring for national governments, non-profits, national research institutions, farmers, scientists and policy-makers. It collates its data from meteorological offices across the continent. Non-profit practical action and education institutes like Binghamton University support Rain Watch.

United Kingdom-based professor of climate science Tim Osborn runs the data collection on and compilation of surface temperatures for the University of East Anglia. He started in 1990 and continued after he completed his Doctor of Philosophy. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has used Osborn's climate modelling in their reporting.

The US Energy Information Administration supplies free and accessible data on electricity, energy production, fossil fuels and carbon dioxide emissions. The US government established the EIA in the 1970s to address the energy crises. It aims to collect, analyze, and disseminate independent and impartial energy information to promote sound policymaking.

Dutch-based and government-funded Koninklijk Nederlands Meteorologisch Instituut supplies the KNMI Climate Explorer database, which supplies temperature, precipitation, cloud cover and pressure, wind speed and emissions from several datasets, including the University of East Anglia and NOAA.  The data is meant for scientists and does not break down information at a country-level.

The database tracks the number of countries, companies and cities that aim to cut their net emissions to zero and to hold entities accountable for their decisions. It tracks the countries that are party to the Paris Agreement. The European Climate Foundation and ClimateWorks Foundation fund the tracker.

report: University of East Anglia’s Climate Research Unit
blurb: The University of East Anglia's climate projections and observations supplied data on climate change and last updated it in 2018. It was a tool to analyse the effect of different emissions scenarios using national averages for temperature and precipitation. Tim Osborn, who managed the site, continues publishing the data HadCRUT4.

The Hamburg-based German Climate Computing Centre manages the World Data Center for Climate, which aims to provide scientists access to climate modelling data and to preserve it. The World Data Center for Climate joined the World Data System in 2003. Scientists can access and submit datasets to the site.

The Italian-based Institute of Economics and EMbeDS at Sant'Anna School of Advanced Studies publishes the Weighted Climate Data Repository with precipitation and temperature data from Climatic Research Unit (CRU TS), Delaware Climate Office, ECMWF's ERA5 and CSIC. The data starting from 1901 can be weighted by population density.
